title: NA homefield advantage
body:
So the World Championship is going to take place in NA this year and only one of those locations is near where the servers league servers are located in NA (Chicago).

Although the actual event will take place on a LAN with almost no ping all of the players will have to practice at various locations with much higher ping then a lot of the "out of town" teams are used to (especially the Korean players). But the NA LCS players have had a whole 2 splits playing dynamic queue with 60+ ping and then playing scrims and real games in a no ping environment.

Do you guys think this will throw off the non-NA players or will they be able to easily adjust between higher and no ping?

replies.body: Most of their practice will also be on zero ping servers. These guys will probably not spend a ton of time on the NA main servers. I don't know what ping they have at home, but it's probably very similar to ours anyway.
According to Doublelift's vlog, the Korean live servers have 8 ms ping. No, that's not a typo; single digit ping on live. He's there with TSM bootcamping.
That's why everyone bootcamps there. Low ping, high competition in Solo Queue, and, if you have connections, you're playing against some of the best teams in the world.

> [{quoted}](name=TurquoiseYoshi,realm=NA,application-id=9hBQwnEU,discussion-id=U6cOVt9P,comment-id=000300000000,timestamp=2016-09-14T01:12:23.958+0000)
>
> That's why everyone bootcamps there. Low ping, high competition in Solo Queue, and, if you have connections, you're playing against some of the best teams in the world.

Not necessarily high competition in korea (from what I've heard from multiple former-lcs player turned streamers the overall competition is about equal). Pretty sure the only reason they train in korea is because it allows the teams to play on a low-ping environment while also scrimming against non-regional teams. Higher competition though, that's highly suspect.

What do you mean "not necessarily high competition" the LCK has literally owned League of Legends the players win every competition year in and year out.  Solo Q in other regions take solo Q very serious and the players take the ranking with pride you don't see (as much) trolling in Korea-China etc as you would in NA.  

In Korea Gold is NA Masters.  That is why you see some many NA-EU players go to Korea and get stuck in Diamond opposed to their challenger elo in NA-EU.  The competition is much harder and more fierce.

> [{quoted}](name=III BAKURYU III ,realm=NA,application-id=9hBQwnEU,discussion-id=U6cOVt9P,comment-id=00030000000000000000,timestamp=2016-09-14T05:32:00.838+0000)

Solo Q in other regions take solo Q very serious and the players take the ranking with pride you don't see (as much) trolling in Korea-China etc as you would in NA.  
> 
> In Korea Gold is NA Masters.  That is why you see some many NA-EU players go to Korea and get stuck in Diamond opposed to their challenger elo in NA-EU.  The competition is much harder and more fierce.

Yeah, the skill that the LCS players have has a lot to do with their rigorous training methods (some spend 14-16hours a day playing this) and not to do with the competition they're facing in solo-queue. I'd also like proof of the "many NA/EU players getting stuck in diamond despite being challenger", as not only is the latter part of that point entirely false (aside from bjerg/biofrost/doublelift/sneaky/jensen/impact/huhi/stixxay, much of NA challenger right now is filled with retired LCS players like QT or people who haven't really had a shot like arcsecond/goldenglue) but after listening to many former pros who did the korean bootcamp thing (IWdom/sneaky/aphromoo) the former also seems to be a pretty massive assumption based off of the notion that koreans are apparently "gods of video games". 

In korea, the competition isn't exactly "more fierce" but instead "more even". Because everyone plays on 8 ping (again, this being one of the two big reasons why many of the professional teams send their players there and not due to skill), server lag get completely eliminated as an issue/excuse for people putting everyone on a more even playing field. If you miss a skillshot there, then 99.9% of the time it's solely your fault for that.
And the Europeans had the homefield advantage last year, and the Koreans the year before that. Your point?
Do.... can people.... read... the actual post?

They scrim and play on the tournament realm so there's not going to be any ping issues at all, for any of the players. If anything, the Koreans will still have the upper hand because that's pretty close to what they play on live at home, which means the rest of the world will have to adjust to the difference. This is only one reason the Koreans almost always dominate LAN events.

"Although the actual event will take place on a LAN with almost no ping"

This is literally the 3rd line in the post. How is it that every comment about the event taking place with high ping.

Because this portion of that same sentence:

> players will have to practice at various locations with much higher ping

... is not true. They will scrim (which is practice) on the same realm the competition will be played on.

http://www.twitlonger.com/show/n_1sn8836

https://twitter.com/FOXKEITHMCBRIEF/status/631019888685879300

http://www.gamespot.com/articles/league-of-legends-pros-unhappy-with-server-move/1100-6429668/

Not likely that there will be a point to trying to change your mind at this point but here are a few links of pros outlining their concerns about the server move when it originally happened. NOW all of the players have to adjust to these changes that the NA LCS pros have gotten used to.

I was hoping to have a discussion on how it will affect the other teams coming in but all anyone seems to want to do is downvote and insist I am clueless about the situation. Maybe people will be more willing to discuss in a few weeks when the pros start talking about it closer to worlds?

You are so ignorant of what people are trying to tell you. Both scrims, and regulated matches are both played on a private server. The pros are only unhappy with the main server move because it is where they play solo-q. Oh, and just a heads up, they are playing less and less solo-q games and more and more scrim blocks, so it actually wont make a difference for foreign team coming to NA, because they scrim almost 100% of the time now. The only reason the pros play solo-q is to make stream revenue. It does not affect their scrim, and professional gameplay whatsoever. They can literally be fine doing 2-4 scrim blocks a day with no solo-q.
tl;dr 
In essence, they wont have adjustment problems, because they wont be using solo-q at all.

Literally NONE of that is new information to me. AND half of it is just NOT true. EVERY single pro player has been hitting soloq in Korea HARD.

http://www.lolking.net/summoner/kr/50516006#profile

This is Zven's Korean account given to him to play soloq in KR. He has played almost 100 games in the less than 2 weeks since they have been there of soloq. To say they don't practice in soloq is a ridiculous made up fabrication of a story. You are the one who is ignorant.

Solo q is individual practice. At times just prior to big tournaments (and tournaments don't get bigger than Worlds) the teams focus primarily on scrims. I understand more clearly what your point is based on, but it is still flawed because--as we have stated--scrims are not played on Live but on the tournament realm.

Considering that everyone bootcamps in Korea where the ping is 8 ms, I think it will throw them off more in the meaningless DQ practice than in an actual Worlds match (obvious exception is before Quarters). And remember, they get lots of pre-game button checks where they get to practice on low-ping before games. 

So no, it probably won't mean anything.
They have like 1 ping at these tournaments because they use a local server. The ping won't matter, but the atmosphere might.

I wasn't referring to the actual games. That is what the whole 2nd paragraph is about.

They still have to practice in dynamic queue though which could mess with their muscle memory in a way they aren't used to. Which is what I was asking about or I guess starting a discussion about.
